item.title: New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2014
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to permanently extend the new markets tax credit, and for other purposes.
New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2014

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: By Mr. GERLACH:H.R. 4365.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The Congress enacts this bill pursuant to Clause 1 ofSection 8 of Article I of the United States Constitution.[Page H2854]

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text: New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2014 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make permanent the new markets tax credit, (2) provide for an inflation adjustment to the limitation amount for such credit after 2013, and (3) allow an offset against the alternative minimum tax (AMT) for such credit (determined with respect to qualified equity investments initially made after the enactment of this Act).

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Workforce Protections.

item.latestTitle: Invest in United States Act of 2014

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
